feed.title: Category: Samuel Adams | BREW PUPPY dot NET

entry.title: Pumpkin Beer Showdown: A Winner is Chosen
entry.content:
At long last, the time to choose a winner is upon us. I gathered up our favorite beers from the last four rounds and took them to a Halloween party to perform a final tasting experiment: eight people, five beers, one winner.

The finalists were chosen from the top four ranked beers plus one wildcard we wanted to taste again compared to the others. Which pumpkin beer will I be drinking exclusively next Fall? Let’s find out.

Beer Rank Rating
O'Fallon - Pumpkin Beer 1 8.5
Buffalo Bill's - Pumpkin Ale 1 8.5
Samuel Adams - Harvest Pumpkin Ale 2 7.5
Blue Moon - Harvest Pumpkin Ale 2 7.5
California Cider Company - Ace Pumpkin Cider 1 7
Schlafly - Pumpkin Ale 3 6.5
Shock Top - Pumpkin Wheat 3 6.5
Samuel Adams - Fat Jack 2 6.5
Shipyard - Smashed Pumpkin 3 6
Mother's - Mr. Pumpkin 1 6
Rogue Farms - Pumpkin Patch Ale 1 6
Horny Goat - HornyCopia 4 5.5
New Belgium - Pumpkick 5 5
Woodchuck - Pumpkin Cider 3 4
Shipyard - Pumpkinhead 4 3.5
Mendocino - Pumpkin Ale 5 2.5
BridgePort - Witch Hunt 4 1

The Tasting

Each participant was asked to rate each beer’s Appearance, Smell, and Taste being either a Positive (), Neutral, or Negative () experience. An option to describe the beer in ten words or less was also given. Some people (me!) had difficulty keeping within the ten word limit. After tasting all five beers, the participants were then asked to rank the beers from Best (1) to Worst (5).

Samuel Adams – Harvest Pumpkin Ale

Taster Appearance Smell Taste Rank
Catwoman 1
Mama Jen 1
Miss Scarlet 5
Colonel Mustard 3
The Host 1
Librarian 1
Pirate 5
Bank Robber 2

Comments

  • Catwoman
    • Good
  • Mama Jen
    • Mellow but smooth
    • Good drinkable beer
  • Miss Scarlet
    • Sharp taste
    • Acetone/Vodka notes at end
    • Skunky smell
  • Colonel Mustard
    • Heavy spice but smooth
    • Minimal beer flavor
    • Biscuity
  • Librarian
    • Spicy
  • Pirate
    • Dark amber color
    • Soft spiced nose
    • Up front bitter quickly resolves to a burned taste
    • Pumpkin patch on fire
  • Bank Robber
    • Pumpkin theme stands out in the nose
    • Dry, complex, improves the more you drink
    • Deep amber not what I would expect from a pumpkin ale
    • Crisp fall day out at the pumpkin patch

O'Fallon – Pumpkin Beer

Taster Appearance Smell Taste Rank
Catwoman 4
Mama Jen 4
Miss Scarlet 3
Colonel Mustard 1
The Host 5
Librarian 5
Pirate 1
Bank Robber 4

Comments

  • Catwoman
    • Just OK
    • Not chuggable
  • Mama Jen
    • No spice
  • Miss Scarlet
    • Savory pumpkin taste without spice
    • More “Beer” taste
    • Good but plain
    • Doesn’t taste very pumpkiny
  • Colonel Mustard
    • Biscuit, Roasty, Coffee
    • Mild pumpkin with caramel
    • Malt accent
    • Mild spice
  • Librarian
    • Watery
  • Pirate
    • Light brown, cloudy
    • Soft sweet nose
    • Sweet pumpkin love
  • Bank Robber
    • Beautiful orange
    • Light body falls a bit flat
    • One-dimensional spices (cinnamon)

Buffalo Bill’s – Pumpkin Ale

Taster Appearance Smell Taste Rank
Catwoman 2
Mama Jen 5
Miss Scarlet ? 2
Colonel Mustard 5
The Host 3
Librarian 4
Pirate 3
Bank Robber 5

Comments

  • Catwoman
    • Chuggable
  • Miss Scarlet
    • Lager? Watery taste
    • Crisp finish
  • Colonel Mustard
    • Skunky smell
  • Librarian
    • Not impressive
  • Pirate
    • Light brown (cloudy)
    • Soft nose of spice and sweet
    • Light, watered down flavor
    • Tastes like a spiced pumpkin tea
  • Bank Robber
    • Unique taste
    • Sweet floral nose but not spice oriented
    • Too much floral/cinnamon to correctly balance

Blue Moon – Harvest Pumpkin Ale

Taster Appearance Smell Taste Rank
Catwoman 3
Mama Jen 2
Miss Scarlet 4
Colonel Mustard 2
The Host 2
Librarian 2
Pirate 4
Bank Robber 3

Comments

  • Catwoman
    • Good but wouldn’t drink more than two
  • Mama Jen
    • Nutmeg
  • Miss Scarlet
    • Pumpkin mid palate
    • Bitter aftertase does not balance
  • Colonel Mustard
    • Spicy pumpkin smell
    • Balance of spice and beer flavors
  • Pirate
    • Clear light brown
    • Sharp spice nose
    • Slight bitterness, good pumpkin flavor with light spice
  • Bank Robber
    • Crystal clear orange
    • Generic aroma
    • Technical ability shows in the taste balance

Schlafly – Pumpkin Ale

Taster Appearance Smell Taste Rank
Catwoman 5
Mama Jen 3
Miss Scarlet 1
Colonel Mustard 4
The Host 4
Librarian 3
Pirate 2
Bank Robber 1

Comments

  • Catwoman
    • Eh
  • Mama Jen
    • Tastes like pumpkin pie
  • Miss Scarlet
    • Good spice taste
    • Semi-sweet wine taste
  • Colonel Mustard
    • Yeasty, metallic smell
    • Heavy spice
    • More pumpkin flavor; no beer
  • Librarian:
    • Very spicey
    • Too pumpkiny
  • Pirate
    • Strong cinnamon nose
    • Pumpkin Pie
  • Bank Robber
    • Deep amber loses out to some of the more vibrant oranges
    • Beautiful spice nose
    • Touch of bitter aftertaste lingers
    • Rich and sweet goodness
    • It’s a freaking pie!

Results

Sam Adams – Harvest Pumpkin Ale proved to be the clear winner of the Pumpkin Beer Showdown. Determining the final ranking of the other beers proved to be a bit more difficult. First, for each beer the participants' rank (1-5) were added together and sorted in descending order to determine the Total Rank.

Total Rank

  1. 19 Sam Adams – Harvest Pumpkin Ale
  2. 22 Blue Moon – Harvest Pumpkin Ale
  3. 24 Schlafly – Pumpkin Ale
  4. 25 O'Fallon – Pumpkin Beer
  5. 30 Buffalo Bill – Pumpkin Ale

Next, for each positive experience a beer would earn 1 points, for each negative experience a beer would earn -1, and for neutral each neutral experience a beer earned 0 points. The points were added together and sorted in ascending order to determine the Overall Experience.

Overall Experience

  1. 9 Sam Adams – Harvest Pumpkin Ale
  2. 8 Schlafly – Pumpkin Ale
  3. 5 O'Fallon – Pumpkin Beer
  4. 4 Blue Moon – Harvest Pumpkin Ale
  5. -2 Buffalo Bill – Pumpkin Ale

Only by averaging the placement of both the Total Rank and the Overall Experience was I able to determine the Final Ranking.

Final Ranking

  1. Sam Adams – Harvest Pumpkin Ale
  2. Schlafly – Pumpkin Ale
  3. Blue Moon – Harvest Pumpkin Ale
  4. O'Fallon – Pumpkin Beer
  5. Buffalo Bill – Pumpkin Ale

entry.title: Pumpkin Beer Showdown: Round 3
entry.content:
After visiting four cities and eleven liquor stores, the area appears to be tapped out of pumpkin beers. I even had to cheat a little just to find enough to fill out this round so you’ll have to forgive me for taking some liberties with the definition of “pumpkin beer.” The final four contenders see if they have what it takes to make it into the coveted Final Round. Which brewery’s Fall creation will emerge from Round 3 victorious? Let’s find out.

Shipyard – Smashed Pumpkin

Smashed Pumpkin is a big-bodied beer with a light coppery orange color and pleasing aromas of pumpkin and nutmeg. The Pale Ale, Wheat and Light Munich malts combine with the natural tannin in pumpkin and the delicate spiciness of hops to balance the sweetness of fruit.

  • OG: 1.088 Plato
  • Malts: Pale Ale, Wheat, Light Munich
  • Hops: Willamette, Hallertau
  • Yeast: Top-Fermenting English

Brew Puppy: 6 / 10

Mild cinnamon and sweet malt nose. Dominant cinnamon and floral flavors. Sweetness of alcohol balances with the vegetal pumpkin flavors. Pleasant bitterness compliments the sweetness without being overwhelming. This double version of their Pumpkinhead tastes far better than the regular version but doesn’t grow on me as I drink it which knocked it down to a six.

The Wife: 6 / 10

Pumpkin allspice nose. Slight bitter front-end and dry finish without a lingering flavor in the mouth. Allspice spice for bittering and cinnamon vegetal flavor.

Samuel Adams – Fat Jack

This rich and luscious brew indulges in flavor with over 28 lbs. of pumpkin per barrel, for a full bodied sweetness and deep russet color. Classic pumpkin pie spices like cinnamon, nutmeg, and allspice ignite a warmth and spark that’s deepened by an undercurrent of roasty smoked malts. The result is a delectable brew full of enveloping layers of flavor and spice.

  • ABV: 8.5% ABV
  • SRM: 25 (Rich copper)
  • IBU: 25
  • Hops: East Kent Goldings, Fuggles
  • Malts: Samuel Adams two-row pale malt blend, rye, Special B, smoked malt
  • Yeast: Samuel Adams ale yeast
  • Special Ingredients: Real pumpkin, cinnamon, ginger, nutmeg, allspice

Brew Puppy: 7 / 10

Medium malt nose with a touch of roasty notes. Pumpkin and malt flavors dominant; not spice heavy at all. Basically a double version of their standard pumpkin ale. Bitter front-end vegetal pumpkin which lingers but pleasantly fades away; a bit more sweetness may have balanced this out. Very complex and grew on me as I drank it until it became my favorite beer of the round.

The Wife: 6 / 10

Soft nose with a slight spiced smell of nutmeg. Good pumpkin flavor. Smooth maltiness with a bitter aftertaste. Vegetal flavors with smooth, complex spice taste.

BridgePort – Witch Hunt

A spiced harvest ale with a rich caramel color, unique dry hop character and subtle hints of cinnamon and nutmeg.

  • OG: 15.8 Plato
  • ABV: 5.8%
  • IBU: 40

Brew Puppy: 1 / 10

Mild malt and nutmeg nose. Overbearing nutmeg front and lingering bitterness which coats the tongue like a sawdust film. The harsh spices are like sawing logs in the Siberia wilderness. I did not drink any more of this beer than I had to.

The Wife: 1 / 10

Soft nutmeg and allspice nose. Too much spice flavor. Bitter front-end and dry bitter finish.

California Cider Company – Ace Pumpkin Cider

We first made this cider three years ago in 2010. We add cinnamon, cloves and allspice to fermented apple juice to produce a 5% cider which tastes like pumpkin pie. It is orange in color with a full rich taste that makes you want more. We carbonate the cider, cold-filter it four times before we bottle and keg it. This cider is released after Labor Day and is ideal for Halloween through Thanksgiving; although some customers think we should make it year round. It is the first Pumpkin cider to be made out West.

Brew Puppy: 6 / 10

Sweet apple cider nose which reminds me of cinnamon apples. Dominant cinnamon taste with apple sweetness and maybe a touch of nutmeg. This beer is like drinking a dessert. Simple flavor with little complexity. The balance is heavy on the sweet side; a dry version would be amazing.

The Wife: 8 / 10

Sweet cider nose with apple allspice aroma. Smooth allspice flavor but minimal pumpkin flavor. Sweet up front with a lingering sweet mouthfeel. Yummy! Dessert in my mouth!

Results

  1. 7
    California Cider Company – Ace Pumpkin Cider
  2. 6.5
    Samuel Adams – Fat Jack
  3. 6
    Shipyard – Smashed Pumpkin
  4. 1
    BridgePort – Witch Hunt

In Case you Missed it:

  • Round 1
  • Round 2

entry.title: Pumpkin Beer Showdown: Round 1
entry.content:
My favorite season of the year is almost upon us. Cooler weather, changing colors, all the best holidays, and of course, seasonal beer. One of the most iconic Autumn styles is the pumpkin beer. While pumpkin beers were produced in the early days of the American colonies, they were different from the pumpkin beers we know today. Colonists used pumpkin and squash as the fermenting medium, since malted barley was scarce. Once malt became more readily available, it replaced these alternatives to grain. In the 1990’s, American craft brewers reintroduced the style to the delight of pumpkin beer drinkers. Five pumpkin beers face off in a head-to-head challenge of seasonal carnage. Which brewery’s Fall creation will emerge victorious? Let’s find out.

New Belgium – Pumpkick

What’s that bite of tartness doing in a pumpkin beer? Adding the unexpected kick of cranberry juice to brighten this traditionally spiced seasonal ale. Pumpkick is brewed with plenty of pumpkin juice, cinnamon, nutmeg, and allspice, but it’s the cranberries and touch of lemongrass that send your taste buds sailing.

  • ABV: 6.0%
  • Hops: Target
  • Malts: Pale, Munich, Caramel
  • Special Ingredients: Pumpkin juice, Cinnamon, Nutmeg, Allspice, Cranberries, Lemongrass

Brew Puppy: 5 / 10

Bold spice nose of nutmeg, allspice, and clove which comes through with a medium intensity in the flavor. There is a touch of fruity esters in the background which I would except from New Belgium. The vegetable/fruit flavor of the pumpkin and the dry finish leaves a gritty coating of spices on my tongue. The blend of spices is great but the finish leaves a residue which ruins the balance of the beer.

The Wife: 5 / 10

Spiced nose, strong of allspice and nutmeg. Weak flavor, pumpkin lacking. Lots of spices in the flavor.

Horny Goat – HornyCopia

We mash in pumpkins with two-row, Vienna and Caramel malts for a hearty ale with just the right amount of body. Spices added to the boil create a complex yet deliciously harmonious flavor. We used pumpkin and spice to yield a brew we proudly describe as “Pumpkin Pie in a Bottle”.

  • ABV: 6.3%
  • IBU: 23

Brew Puppy: 4 / 10

Sweet malty nose and good nutmeg aroma which comes through mild yet dominant in the flavor on top of a solid malt base. Finish is light and airy, but the nutmeg bitterness lingers, compounding with each drink and ruining the beer for me after only a few drinks.

The Wife: 7 / 10

Soft, sweet nose with little spice smell. Smooth malt flavor, dry finish. Good pumpkin up front.

Schlafly – Pumpkin Ale

Our Pumpkin Ale blends the spices of the harvest with full-bodied sweetness for a beer that tastes like pumpkin pie. Pounds of pumpkin form a malty foundation that supports the fall flavors of cinnamon, nutmeg and clove.

  • OG: 18.5 Plato
  • ABV: 8.0%
  • IBU: 16
  • SRM: 27 (Copper-colored, bright)
  • Malts: Pale, Crystal, Munich, Wheat, Chocolate
  • Hops: Marynka (PL)
  • Yeast: American Ale
  • Special Ingredients: pumpkin squash and a blend of spices

Brew Puppy: 6 / 10

Allspice comes through in the nose and is the dominant spice in the flavor with a medium intensity. Darker malts, possibly crystal, sweeten this beer up and ends with a pleasant, medium dry finish. While the sweetness sets this beer apart from the others, the extra flavors makes this beer a bit heavier and not as easy to drink.

The Wife: 7 / 10

Soft nose of nutmeg and allspice. Too much nutmeg and not enough malt flavor. Bitter back-end. Too much spice, not enough everything else.

O'Fallon – Pumpkin Beer

Like pumpkin pie in a bottle…we add 136 pounds of real pumpkin to the three-barley mash and then season the finished beer with cinnamon, nutmeg and cloves.

  • ABV: 5.6%
  • IBU: 11
  • SRM 8.7
  • Malts: Pale, White Wheat, Caramel 90L
  • Hops: Cluster

Brew Puppy: 8 / 10

A sweet cinnamon nose with a good balance between the spices and hop bitterness. The spice flavors did not dominate but instead complimented the malts well; very well balanced.

The Wife: 9 / 10

Sweet nose of cinnamon and nutmeg. Sweet pumpkin flavor with very little pumpkin back-end or bitterness. Slight malt flavor. Good body.

Samuel Adams – Harvest Pumpkin Ale

Smooth, rich, and roasty with over 17 lbs. of real pumpkin & warming spices like ginger, cinnamon & nutmeg give this brew a smooth inviting character. This style, first brewed by American colonists, is hearty and spicy making it perfect for the crisper days of fall.

  • ABV: 5.7%
  • IBU: 14
  • SRM: 33 (Dark reddish amber)
  • Malts: Samuel Adams two-row pale malt blend, Caramel 60, Special B, smoked malt
  • Hops: East Kent Goldings, Fuggles
  • Yeast: Top-fermenting Ale
  • Special Ingredients: Real pumpkin, cinnamon, ginger, nutmeg, allspice

Brew Puppy: 7 / 10

The aroma is nutty with a hint of nutmeg. Vegetal pumpkin taste come through with a nice spice seasoning. Smooth, clean finish indicative of a lager beer. This beer is how I imagine the original pumpkin beers may have tasted.

The Wife: 8 / 10

Spiced nose of allspice and nutmeg. Sweet spice and malty flavor. No real hop bitterness noted; any bitterness is from pumpkin flavors. Tastes like it smells.

Results

  1. 8.5
    O'Fallon – Pumpkin Beer
  2. 7.5
    Samuel Adams – Harvest Pumpkin Ale
  3. 6.5
    Schlafly – Pumpkin Ale
  4. 5.5
    Horny Goat – HornyCopia
  5. 5
    New Belgium – Pumpkick

entry.title: Tasting of Samuel Adams - Merry Mischief
entry.content:
This rich dark gingerbread stout entices with the aromas of the holidays. The flavor of gingerbread comes alive, beginning with the smooth sweetness and heartiness of dark roasted malts and a touch of wheat. But it’s the intensity and spices of cinnamon, clove, nutmeg, & ginger that add a wicked kick for a jolly playful brew full of merry mischief.

  • Batch Number: 1
  • Hops:
    • East Kent Goldings
    • Fuggles
  • Malts:
    • Samuel Adams two row pale malt blend
    • Wheat
    • Special B
    • Paul’s Roasted Barley
    • Flaked Oats
  • Special Ingredients:
    • Cinnamon
    • Clove
    • Nutmeg
    • Ginger
  • Yeast: Samuel Adams ale yeast
  • Color: 200 SRM
  • ABV: 9.0%
  • IBUs: 25

Brewer’s Tasting Notes

While no gingerbread went into this beer, the sweet roastiness with hints of cocoa and a slight nuttiness from the dark malts provide a similar comparison to gingerbread. A blend of nutmeg, cinnamon, cloves, and ginger were used to create a layer of complexity and lingering heat.

What I Expected

Everything about this beer from description, the ingredients, the name, even the label screams Christmas/Winter Specialty Spiced Beer (21B) so I will use this style as a benchmark for my tasting. The inclusion of flaked oats and low IBUs has me guessing the base style is an Oatmeal Stout (13C).

  • Aroma – A bold spice nose which will hopefully remind me of gingerbread cookies with the help of roasted grain aromas. I would guess the hops were used primarily for bittering and any hop aroma will be absent.
  • Appearance – If the reported IBU is correct, I would expect quite a dark, black beer impossible to see through with a thick, creamy, tan/brown-colored head.
  • Flavor – The spices and higher alcohol content should contribute a warm, complex flavor set on top of a solid oats and roasted dark grain base balanced by a moderate bitterness from the hops.

Tasting Notes

  • Appearance – Very black with a dark, tan head which was quite thick on the first poor. Opaque to the point of no visible light through the glass.
  • Aroma – Clove and spices dominate the aroma, whether you’re trying to smell the beer or not; no hop aroma.
  • Flavor – The spices of the aroma come through first, followed by roasted grains and an alcohol warmth. Carbonation was a bit higher than I expected from a stout but works wells with the warmth of the alcohol.

Conclusion: Outstanding (41 / 45)

Guest Tasters

  • The Wife: Outstanding (42 / 45)
  • Adam (Placebo Effect): Excellent (34 / 45)

Appearance: 3 / 3

The color and head of this beer was exactly what I expected it which deserves a perfect score. The reported SRM is more believable after you’ve seen this beer first hand.

  • The Wife: 3 / 3
    • Dark Brown
    • Creamy Head
    • Defined Legs
  • Adam (Placebo Effect): 3 / 3
    • Black
    • Tan, Medium Head Size, Medium-Low Head Retention
    • Opaque

Aroma: 11 / 12

Spices, particularly cloves, dominate the aroma and in my opinion overpower any grains that may have been present. Besides the lack of roasted grain notes this what I expected.

  • The Wife: 11 / 12
    • Spiced Smell with Cookie Bread
  • Adam (Placebo Effect): 9 / 12
    • Bready, Medium-High Malt
    • Piney
    • Spice
    • Smells Similar to Wassail

Flavor: 18 / 20

Spices, check. Alcohol warmth, check. Roasted grains, um…maybe. Just short of perfect, the overpowering spices have masked any significant grain flavors I hoped to find but not in a bad way, hence the high but not perfect score.

  • The Wife: 18 / 20
    • Smooth
    • Creamy
    • Spiced
  • Adam (Placebo Effect): 15 / 20
    • Toasty
    • Piney, Spicy
    • Banana
    • Spice
    • Malty Balance
    • Tastes Similar to Wassail
    • For something with this much flavor, it should have been heavier

Overall Impression: 9 / 10

I would probably only drink one (large) glass of this beer in a night but oh man would I enjoy that one beer. It is important to note that there is a small window of opportunity in which this beer can be fully appreciated and July is not one of those times. However, this beer sets the bar for all Christmas beers to follow.

  • The Wife: 10 / 10
    • Front-end acidic but balances with spices
    • I really like it; please send me the recipe!
  • Adam (Placebo Effect): 7 / 10
    • I would drink a pint of this beer, however I wouldn’t fathom drinking this beer in a non-holiday context

entry.title: Tasting of Samuel Adams - Tasman Red
entry.content:
This wily red IPA gets its character from the Tasmanian hops that are full of grapefruit, pine, and earthy notes creating a bold flavor that threads throughout the taste. The hops are balanced by a core of roasty malts that give this brew body and richness with hints of toffee. This flavorful brew is rounded and smooth with a dry and citrusy hop finish.

  • Batch Number: 1
  • Hops:
    • Topaz
    • Galaxy
  • Malts:
    • Samuel Adams two-row pale malt blend
    • Special B
    • Caramel 60
    • Carafa III
  • Yeast: Top-fermenting Ale
  • Color: Rich garnet, 45 SRM
  • ABV: 6.5%
  • IBUs: 50

Brewer’s Tasting Notes:

  • While no grapefruit was used in this beer, the use of Topaz and Galaxy hops give this beer a bold hop character taste/aroma that can be compared to a grapefruit.
  • No caramel was used in this beer, though roasty caramel notes can be picked up through a blend of different malts.

What I Expected

Jim Koch has a great tasting video which I used to base my expectations. It’s only a few minutes long but offers great insight into this particular beer.

A big malt front to it and a big hop finish.

Jim Koch Tasting Video http://www.samueladams.com/craft-beers/tasman-red Tasman Red

The use of IPA in the name immediately puts this in the style India Pale Ale. An ABV under 7.5% rules out 14C Imperial IPA. The special malts used in this beer push the SRM far above either the English IPA (14A) or American IPA (14B) styles. With all the malts in this beer it doesn’t look like it will fit under any of the classic styles. If I had to pick one to judge it on though, it would be American IPA for the Aroma and Flavor described. I’m a big fan of hops from Down Under (oh Nelson Sauvin, I want to go there) so I’m excited these are the highlight of the beer.

  • Appearance – Deep ruby red which really come across as a beer which takes malt seriously; the color should reflect this idea. Malt flavors are not joking matter folks.
  • Aroma – I’m looking for the malts to make an appearance and not be overpowered by the hops. Specific smells I’d like to see (smell?) are caramel and toffee as well as grapefruit and pine from the hops.
  • Flavor – The flavor should be exactly what I smelled. sweet caramel toffee with some roasted notes balanced by lots of grapefruit and citrus along with spruce and pine for a resiny finish.

Tasting Notes

  • Appearance – Deep red, a bit hazy. Pours beautifully with a full creamy head.
  • Aroma – Definitely picking up on the citrus and pine of the hops but the malt was lost to me until the beer set for a few minutes, and only then did caramel flavors dominated the aroma.
  • Flavor – Where the aroma failed, the taste certainly delivered. Roasty and caramel malt flavors which transitioned to the resinous hops which then transitioned into a grapefruit bitterness on the end. After the first few drinks when my palate was used to the bitterness the malt flavors really started to come and took a front seat.

Conclusion: Excellent (40 / 45)

Appearance: 2 / 3

The color was exactly what I expected though the lack of clarity was a bit surprising coming from a professional such as Samuel Adams.

Aroma: 10 / 12

At first I was a bit disappointed with the aroma being hop-centric and out of the gate this beer smells like any other American IPA. However, when I smelled again after sitting a while, the malts were there for my enjoyment.

Flavor: 19 / 20

Two words: flavor delivers. This beer lives up to the promise of big malt front and a big hop finish; exactly what I expected. The caramel and resin flavors blend wonderfully. The lower IBU makes it very drinkable as only the malts linger on the palate. I would recommend this beer drank at a warmer temperature to fully appreciate the malt flavors. Maybe not as much grapefruit as what I was expecting so I docked it one point.

Overall Impression: 9 / 10

A complex beer which felt like a three-stage rocket to drink. This is something I would definitely buy again when I want a one-off IPA. I would recommend this beer to IPA drinkers who are looking for something different. I would not recommend this beer to Red Ale drinkers unless you’re feeling particularly bold. While there are pleasant malt flavors the hops dominate this beer as any true IPA should and is nothing similar to the styles you may be used to drinking.
